29.title: La Mousse, Madame
29.author: De Beck
29.series: Oct. 17, 1930) "These Priceless Jewels Were My Gift To Her"*
29.appears_in: p. 158 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Senator Schnopps explains to Zitz that he is in love with Madame La Mousse, a princess and the world's most beautiful woman, but she sent back the jewels and is infatuated with Google.

30.title: La Mousse, Madame
30.author: De Beck
30.series: Oct. 18, 1939) "Tom Tom the Black Senegalese Would Die For Her"*
30.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Madame La Mousse has become infatuated with Barney after seeing his picture. She has pet lions and leopards, and a caricatured African servant.

31.title: La Mousse, Madame
31.author: De Beck
31.series: Oct. 20, 1930) "The Lady Awaits, Come at Once"*
31.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Shows and describes the current cast of characters: Tom-Tom, Senator Schnopps, Barney, Zitz, Madame La Mousse, and Lena her pet, a big cat shown here with stripes like a tiger.

32.title: La Mousse, Madame
32.author: De Beck
32.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney is going to call on Madame La Mousse, because "that Arab of hers" brought an invitation. Zitz warns him about tigers and leopards, so Barney goes to buy some raw meat.

33.title: La Mousse, Madame
33.author: De Beck
33.series: Oct. 22, 1930) "Tell La Mousse that Bubble Eyes is Here"*
33.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Tom-Tom lets Barney in, and as he waits a leopard approaches.

34.title: La Mousse, Madame
34.author: De Beck
34.series: Oct. 23, 1930) "Lena, Madame La Mousse's Favorite Leopard"*
34.appears_in: p. 159 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney runs when he first faces Lena, and says he's through courting. Then he gets another love note and goes to the zoo to get used to big cats.

35.title: La Mousse, Madame
35.author: De Beck
35.series: Oct. 25, 1930) "This Nest Gives Me the Creeps"*
35.appears_in: p. 160 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney waits for La Mousse, and meanwhile the leopard is caged and Tom Tom plays the violin.

36.title: La Mousse, Madame
36.author: De Beck
36.appears_in: p. 160 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney finally sees La Mousse, and he runs away.

37.title: La Mousse, Madame
37.author: De Beck
37.series: Oct. 28, 1930) "The Music Will Quiet Your Nerves"*
37.appears_in: p. 160 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Senator Schnopps is distraught because Barney is visiting La Mousse. Zitz turns on the radio, and a man is singing a song called "Bubble Eyes."

38.title: La Mousse, Madame
38.author: De Beck
38.series: Oct. 29, 1930) "If She Only Had That Nose o' Hers Fixed"*
38.appears_in: p. 160 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney gets to know Madame La Mousse.

39.title: La Mousse, Madame
39.author: De Beck
39.appears_in: p. 161 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Schnopps and Zitz are going to try to make La Mousse jealous by introducing an 'other woman.'

40.title: La Mousse, Madame
40.author: De Beck
40.series: Nov. 12, 1930) "I Saw Her Make a Sign to that Cannibal Servant"*
40.appears_in: p. 163 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney makes an excuse to not vist Madame la Mousse tomorrow night, then he worries about Tom-Tom and his spears.

41.title: La Mousse, Madame
41.author: De Beck
41.series: Nov. 13, 1930) "I Hope She Ain't Got a Beezer On Her Like Ol' Lady La Mousse"*
41.appears_in: p. 163 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney prepares to meet Opal Showers.

42.title: La Mousse, Madame
42.author: De Beck
42.series: Nov. 15, 1930) "Their Wedding Should Be the Social Event of the Season"*
42.appears_in: p. 163 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: Barney wants to take Senator Schnopps's offer and leave for China, Zitz thinks his plan is working out fine and the senator will marry Madame La Mousse, Opal thinks Barney is a real gentleman, and Tom-Tom is encouraging Barney (with his spear) to go back to La Mousse.

43.title: La Mousse, Madame
43.author: De Beck
43.appears_in: p. 164 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: La Mousse is not pleased that Barney broke their date, Barney says Opal is his cousin and thinks he's gotten away with it, but a house cat spooks him.

44.title: La Mousse, Madame
44.author: De Beck
44.series: Nov. 18, 1930) "Miss Opal is Having Dinner With me This Evening"*
44.appears_in: p. 164 in The Smithsonian Collection of Newspaper Comics, ed. by Bill Blackbeard and Martin Williams (Washington, D.C. : Smithsonian Institution Press, 1977).
notes: Summary: The senator now seems more interested in Opal Showers than in Madame La Mousse.

Other title: Disney Aladdin.

Summary (from SkyRiver): Jasmine, princess of Agrabah, tells how she met Aladdin, a street-smart young thief. When evil Jafar plots to steal the Genie's lamp from Aladdin, to further his own rise to power, it's Aladdin's courage that saves the day and wins Jasmine's heart.

128.heading: Lamps.
128.title: Sai Baba.
128.author: [No author]
notes: (Wilco Picture Library ; v. MHD-036)
"Series Indian mythology & tales/ history/divinity."
"For all ages."

"Saibaba, one of the most popular and beloved saints of modern India, is popular among Hindus as well as Muslims. Hardly anybody knows where he was born and from where he came to Shirdi, but Shirdi in Maharashtra where he lived for most of his life is one of the most visited pilgrimage places. This title on Saibaba, who some say was Muslim and some Hindu, will enlighten you about the important events of his life, such as lighting lamps with water instead of oil, when the grocers refused to give him free oil."
